Line 19: Line 19:
==Biography==
==Biography==
===2004-2005: ''Rebelde''===
===2004-2005: ''Rebelde''===
â
[[Image:Rebelde.jpg|thumb|left|''Rebelde'', First Studio Album in Spanish]]RBD debuted in November 30, 2004 with the album ''[[Rebelde (album)|Rebelde]]'', released through [[EMI]].
  â  
The main writers and producers for the project were Carlos Lara (aka D.J. Kafka) and Max di Carlo, and their songs proved popular. The first three singles ("[[Rebelde (song)|Rebelde]]", "[[Solo quÃ©date en silencio|Solo QuÃ©date en Silencio]]" and "[[SÃ¡lvame]]") were all number one hits in Mexico, with the fourth single, "[[Un poco de tu amor|Un Poco de Tu Amor]]" reaching number two.
The main writers and producers for the project were Carlos Lara (aka D.J. Kafka) and Max di Carlo, and their songs proved popular. The first three singles ("[[Rebelde (song)|Rebelde]]", "[[Solo quÃ©date en silencio|Solo QuÃ©date en Silencio]]" and "[[SÃ¡lvame]]") were all number one hits in Mexico, with the fourth single, "[[Un poco de tu amor|Un Poco de Tu Amor]]" reaching number two.
Line 30: Line 28:
===2005: ''Nuestro Amor''===
===2005: ''Nuestro Amor''===
â
[[Image:Nuestroamorrbd.jpg|thumb|left|''Nuestro Amor'' Second Studio Album in Spanish]]In October 2005 came their second studio album, ''[[Nuestro Amor]]'', produced by Carlos Lara which set new sales records in Mexico, selling 127,000 copies one the day of release{{fact|date=December 2008}}, and 500,000 copies in its first week alone{{fact|date=December 2008}}.
+
In October 2005 came their second studio album, ''[[Nuestro Amor]]'', produced by Carlos Lara which set new sales records in Mexico, selling 127,000 copies one the day of release{{fact|date=December 2008}}, and 500,000 copies in its first week alone{{fact|date=December 2008}}.
In the U.S., the album topped the Latin Albums Chart for 3 weeks and again broke into the overall Top 100 (#88).
In the U.S., the album topped the Latin Albums Chart for 3 weeks and again broke into the overall Top 100 (#88).
The first four singles hit number one in Mexico.
The first four singles hit number one in Mexico.
Line 39: Line 37:
===2005-2006: ''Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brasil)''===
===2005-2006: ''Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brasil)''===
â
[[Image:RBD - Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brasil).jpg|thumb|left|''Rebelde - EdiÃ§Ã£o Brasil'' First Studio Album in Portuguese]]In November 2005 a [[Portuguese language]]d edition of the album was released for the Brazilian market called ''[[Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brasil)]]''.
+
In November 2005 a [[Portuguese language]]d edition of the album was released for the Brazilian market called ''[[Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brasil)]]''.
Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brazil) is the Brazilian version of the album Rebelde, the Mexican group RBD. Disk 7 has versions in Portuguese written by ClÃ¡udio Rabello from the original songs in Spanish, in addition to 4 songs from the original disc in Spanish. Was launched in 2005 and reached the mark of more than 200 thousand copies sold.
Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brazil) is the Brazilian version of the album Rebelde, the Mexican group RBD. Disk 7 has versions in Portuguese written by ClÃ¡udio Rabello from the original songs in Spanish, in addition to 4 songs from the original disc in Spanish. Was launched in 2005 and reached the mark of more than 200 thousand copies sold.
Line 48: Line 46:
===2006: ''Nosso Amor Rebelde''===
===2006: ''Nosso Amor Rebelde''===
â
[[Image:RBD Nosso Amor.jpg|thumb|left|''Nosso Amor Rebelde'' Second Studio Album in Portuguese]]Not long after, in May 2006, they released a Portuguese version of ''[[Nuestro Amor]]'', entitled ''[[Nosso Amor Rebelde|Nosso Amor Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brasil)]]'', specially for the Brazilian fans.
+
Not long after, in May 2006, they released a Portuguese version of ''[[Nuestro Amor]]'', entitled ''[[Nosso Amor Rebelde|Nosso Amor Rebelde (EdiÃ§Ã£o Brasil)]]'', specially for the Brazilian fans.
Nosso Amor Rebelde is the second album in the Portuguese Mexican group RBD. Launched only in Brazil in May 2006, the disc contains versions of 11 songs from the original disc in Spanish, Nuestro Amor.
Nosso Amor Rebelde is the second album in the Portuguese Mexican group RBD. Launched only in Brazil in May 2006, the disc contains versions of 11 songs from the original disc in Spanish, Nuestro Amor.
Line 61: Line 59:
===2006: ''Celestial''===
===2006: ''Celestial''===
â
[[Image:Celestial (album).jpg|thumb|left|''Celestial'' Third Studio Album in Spanish]]In November 2006, they released their third studio album ''[[Celestial (RBD album)|Celestial]]'' produced and directed by Carlos Lara which debuted at number 15 in the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], marking first-week sales of over 137,000 copies in the U.S.
+
In November 2006, they released their third studio album ''[[Celestial (RBD album)|Celestial]]'' produced and directed by Carlos Lara which debuted at number 15 in the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], marking first-week sales of over 137,000 copies in the U.S.
The album however did not have a full week of album sales, due to its Friday release. Despite this, it became their first album to peak or chart within the top 20 of the Billboard 200.<ref>[http://billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003465594 First (and only) debut within top 20]</ref>
The album however did not have a full week of album sales, due to its Friday release. Despite this, it became their first album to peak or chart within the top 20 of the Billboard 200.<ref>[http://billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003465594 First (and only) debut within top 20]</ref>
Line 70: Line 68:
===2006-2007: ''Celestial (VersÃ£o Brasil)''===
===2006-2007: ''Celestial (VersÃ£o Brasil)''===
â
[[Image:RBD - Celestial (VersÃ£o Brasil).jpg|thumb|left|''Celestial - VersÃ£o Brasil'' Third Studio Album in Portuguese]]One month later, in December 2006 a Portuguese languaged edition of the album was released for the Brazilian market called ''[[Celestial (VersÃ£o Brasil)]]''.This 3rd album in Portuguese was the first to be recorded in Brazil.
+
One month later, in December 2006 a Portuguese languaged edition of the album was released for the Brazilian market called ''[[Celestial (VersÃ£o Brasil)]]''.This 3rd album in Portuguese was the first to be recorded in Brazil.
From their tour of Brazil, RBD released a DVD entitled ''[[Live in Rio]]''. They were also honored for selling over 2,5 million copies of their albums and DVDs sold in Brazil. Meanwhile, in Spain, ''Rebelde'' spent 5 weeks on the top of the charts going 2x platinum for sales over 160,000. ''[[Nuestro Amor]]'' sold enough to be certified 2x platinum as well, while ''[[Celestial (RBD album)|Celestial]]'', that came out on March 12, 2007, has been certified gold after only being in the chart for three weeks.<ref>[http://www.los40.com/actualidad/listas/afyve.html Spanish Albums Chart with certification sales] at ''[[Los 40 Principales|Los40]].com''</ref>
From their tour of Brazil, RBD released a DVD entitled ''[[Live in Rio]]''. They were also honored for selling over 2,5 million copies of their albums and DVDs sold in Brazil. Meanwhile, in Spain, ''Rebelde'' spent 5 weeks on the top of the charts going 2x platinum for sales over 160,000. ''[[Nuestro Amor]]'' sold enough to be certified 2x platinum as well, while ''[[Celestial (RBD album)|Celestial]]'', that came out on March 12, 2007, has been certified gold after only being in the chart for three weeks.<ref>[http://www.los40.com/actualidad/listas/afyve.html Spanish Albums Chart with certification sales] at ''[[Los 40 Principales|Los40]].com''</ref>
Line 78: Line 76:
===2006-2007: ''Rebels''===
===2006-2007: ''Rebels''===
â
[[Image:RBD Rebels.jpg|thumb|left|''Rebels'' First Studio Album in English]]Fifteen days later, ever in December 2006, they released their first English album, ''[[Rebels (album)|Rebels]]'' which debuted at number 40 on the ''Billboard'' 200 album chart with first-week sales of 94,000 copies.
+
Fifteen days later, ever in December 2006, they released their first English album, ''[[Rebels (album)|Rebels]]'' which debuted at number 40 on the ''Billboard'' 200 album chart with first-week sales of 94,000 copies.
They have been nominated twice in the category for "Latin Pop Album of the Year By a Duo or Group", with ''Celestial'' and ''Live in Hollywood'', which were both released in 2006. They also received a nomination for "Top Latin Albums Artist of the Year" and "Latin Tour of the Year" for the below mentioned Tour GeneraciÃ³n 2006.<ref name="2007 BLMA nominations">[http://artists.letssingit.com/artist-84gtp/news/213726 2007 Billboard Latin Music Awards nominations]</ref> The show was be held on April 26 in [[Miami]]. They won in all categories they were nominated in; ''Celestial'' was the one which won the "Latin Pop Album of the Year By a Duo or Group" award.<ref name="2007 BLMA winners">[http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/awards/index.jsp Billboard Latin Music Awards winners]</ref> The group has also prepared their 2007 world tour called ''Tour Celestial 2007'', starting in [[Ecuador]] on April 20. They were invited by [[Donald Trump]] to perform 3 songs at the [[Miss Universe 2007|2007 Miss Universe]] final in Mexico City, on May 28, 2007. The group performed a medley of "[[Wanna Play]]", "CariÃ±o Mio" and "Money Money" in the event. In June 2007, RBD recorded the video for "[[BÃ©same sin miedo|BÃ©same Sin Miedo]]" in [[Transylvania]], while touring in [[Romania]], where ''Celestial'' was also released. It was the same year they were chosen to headline, along with [[Black Eyed Peas]], a series of [[Pepsi]] commercials to air on South America and Spanish-speaking countries. On July 19, 2007, RBD performed their single "BÃ©same Sin Miedo" at Premios Juventud 2007, and also won 7 awards that night, including "Voice of the Moment" and "Favorite Concert". They had won a total of 24 Premios Juventud awards by then. On July 20, 2007, RBD showed their new tour bus on ''El Gordo y la Flaca'' for their Celestial World Tour]. On July 25, 2007, RBD performed and acoustic concert in Mexico City as part of a new Ritmoson Latino Show called ''Confesiones en Concierto''. The group has become such a phenomenon they have been nominated as best international song of "[[Tu Amor]]" in [[France]] proving their huge success. They sang the single "[[BÃ©same Sin Miedo]]" in "Buscando a Timbiriche" and sang "Mexico" alongside with [[Timbiriche]], a popular group in the 80s and 90s.
They have been nominated twice in the category for "Latin Pop Album of the Year By a Duo or Group", with ''Celestial'' and ''Live in Hollywood'', which were both released in 2006. They also received a nomination for "Top Latin Albums Artist of the Year" and "Latin Tour of the Year" for the below mentioned Tour GeneraciÃ³n 2006.<ref name="2007 BLMA nominations">[http://artists.letssingit.com/artist-84gtp/news/213726 2007 Billboard Latin Music Awards nominations]</ref> The show was be held on April 26 in [[Miami]]. They won in all categories they were nominated in; ''Celestial'' was the one which won the "Latin Pop Album of the Year By a Duo or Group" award.<ref name="2007 BLMA winners">[http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/awards/index.jsp Billboard Latin Music Awards winners]</ref> The group has also prepared their 2007 world tour called ''Tour Celestial 2007'', starting in [[Ecuador]] on April 20. They were invited by [[Donald Trump]] to perform 3 songs at the [[Miss Universe 2007|2007 Miss Universe]] final in Mexico City, on May 28, 2007. The group performed a medley of "[[Wanna Play]]", "CariÃ±o Mio" and "Money Money" in the event. In June 2007, RBD recorded the video for "[[BÃ©same sin miedo|BÃ©same Sin Miedo]]" in [[Transylvania]], while touring in [[Romania]], where ''Celestial'' was also released. It was the same year they were chosen to headline, along with [[Black Eyed Peas]], a series of [[Pepsi]] commercials to air on South America and Spanish-speaking countries. On July 19, 2007, RBD performed their single "BÃ©same Sin Miedo" at Premios Juventud 2007, and also won 7 awards that night, including "Voice of the Moment" and "Favorite Concert". They had won a total of 24 Premios Juventud awards by then. On July 20, 2007, RBD showed their new tour bus on ''El Gordo y la Flaca'' for their Celestial World Tour]. On July 25, 2007, RBD performed and acoustic concert in Mexico City as part of a new Ritmoson Latino Show called ''Confesiones en Concierto''. The group has become such a phenomenon they have been nominated as best international song of "[[Tu Amor]]" in [[France]] proving their huge success. They sang the single "[[BÃ©same Sin Miedo]]" in "Buscando a Timbiriche" and sang "Mexico" alongside with [[Timbiriche]], a popular group in the 80s and 90s.
===2007-2008: ''Empezar Desde Cero''===
===2007-2008: ''Empezar Desde Cero''===
â
[[Image:RBD Empezar Desde Cero.jpg|thumb|left|''Empezar Desde Cero'' Fourth Studio Album in Spanish]]The first worldwide "RBD Day" was held on October 4, 2007. RBD celebrated the day with many fans in Houston, Texas, and during their press conference they confirmed that their fourth Spanish studio album would be titled [[Empezar Desde Cero]], produced again by Carlos Lara and Armando Avila. The first single from [[Empezar Desde Cero]], [[Inalcanzable]], debuted on October of 2007 and peaked at #2 in Mexican charts. [[Empezar Desde Cero]] was released November 20th, debuting on #1 on the Billboard Latin Charts, and peaking at the top 5 in a variety of countries such as Brazil (beign their first album not to top the charts in that country, peaking at #3) and Mexico. As of November 2008, [[Empezar Desde Cero]] had sold over 2 million copies worldwide. It was also voted by Billboard Readers as the third best album released in 2007. <ref>[http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/yearend/2007/readers/index.html "2007 Billboard Readers Choice"]. ''Billboard''. Retrieved April 23, 2008.</ref>
+
The first worldwide "RBD Day" was held on October 4, 2007. RBD celebrated the day with many fans in Houston, Texas, and during their press conference they confirmed that their fourth Spanish studio album would be titled [[Empezar Desde Cero]], produced again by Carlos Lara and Armando Avila. The first single from [[Empezar Desde Cero]], [[Inalcanzable]], debuted on October of 2007 and peaked at #2 in Mexican charts. [[Empezar Desde Cero]] was released November 20th, debuting on #1 on the Billboard Latin Charts, and peaking at the top 5 in a variety of countries such as Brazil (beign their first album not to top the charts in that country, peaking at #3) and Mexico. As of November 2008, [[Empezar Desde Cero]] had sold over 2 million copies worldwide. It was also voted by Billboard Readers as the third best album released in 2007. <ref>[http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/yearend/2007/readers/index.html "2007 Billboard Readers Choice"]. ''Billboard''. Retrieved April 23, 2008.</ref>
The second single from the album was the title-track [[Empezar Desde Cero]]. The song performed better than [[Inalcanzable]], peaking at #1 in many countries and became a Top 15 hit on Billboard Latin Charts. A third, radio-only single from the album, [[Y No Puedo Olvidarte]], was released, to few airplay (it peaked on #31 on Mexico). It has been said to be the final single from the album. In mid-2008, RBD released the special edition of [[Empezar Desde Cero]], featuring three bonus tracks and a bonus DVD.
The second single from the album was the title-track [[Empezar Desde Cero]]. The song performed better than [[Inalcanzable]], peaking at #1 in many countries and became a Top 15 hit on Billboard Latin Charts. A third, radio-only single from the album, [[Y No Puedo Olvidarte]], was released, to few airplay (it peaked on #31 on Mexico). It has been said to be the final single from the album. In mid-2008, RBD released the special edition of [[Empezar Desde Cero]], featuring three bonus tracks and a bonus DVD.
Line 92: Line 90:

===2008-2009: ''Best Of RBD''===
â
[[Image:BestOfRBDCD+DVD.jpg|thumb|left|''Best Of RBD'' Second Compilation Album]]On August 14th 2008, RBD announced through a press release that they would disband in 2009. <ref name="Comunicado de RBD">[http://www2.esmas.com/rbd/fotos/comunicado-rbd/9543]</ref>.
+
On August 14th 2008, RBD announced through a press release that they would disband in 2009. <ref name="Comunicado de RBD">[http://www2.esmas.com/rbd/fotos/comunicado-rbd/9543]</ref>.

Line 120: Line 118:
===2009: ''Para Olvidarte De MÃ­''===
===2009: ''Para Olvidarte De MÃ­''===
â
[[Image:Para Olvidarte De Mi.jpg|thumb|left|''Para Olvidarte De MÃ­'' Fifth Studio Album in Spanish]][[Para Olvidarte De MÃ­]] is slated to be RBD's fifth and final album, marking the end of the successful pop sextet after their four-year career. It will be released March 10, 2009.
+
[[Para Olvidarte De MÃ­]] is slated to be RBD's fifth and final album, marking the end of the successful pop sextet after their four-year career. It will be released March 10, 2009.
Although RBD has said they have not planned any promotion of it, there could be a short tour to promote the CD.
Although RBD has said they have not planned any promotion of it, there could be a short tour to promote the CD.
